Machine learning and traditional algorithms are substantially different ways of computing. Researchers are starting to use machine learning to improve the performance of traditional algorithms. This article provides examples of how machine learning is being used to enhance traditional algorithms: 1. Optimization: Machine learning techniques can be used to optimize traditional algorithms. For instance, in the case of linear regression, machine learning can be used to find the optimal values of the parameters that minimize the loss function faster than classical optimization techniques. 2. Classification: Machine learning algorithms, such as decision trees and neural networks, are being used to improve the accuracy of traditional classification algorithms. For example, in speech recognition, machine learning can help improve the accuracy of classifying spoken words. 3. Image recognition: Traditional algorithms are commonly used in image recognition tasks. However, machine learning is being used to enhance these algorithms. For example, a deep learning algorithm can be used to classify images with a higher level of accuracy. 4. Natural language processing: Machine learning algorithms can also be used to improve the performance of traditional techniques in natural language processing. For instance, machine learning algorithms can be used to improve the accuracy of named entity recognition and part-of-speech tagging. In general, machine learning can be used to improve the performance of traditional algorithms by providing a more efficient way to search through a large space of possible solutions. By leveraging machine learning techniques, researchers are able to optimize traditional algorithms and improve their accuracy in a wide range of applications.

While businesses are complaining about the shortage of workers, older job seekers are finding that even with the right qualifications for the job, they are being turned away due to ageism. Ageism is a form of discrimination which results in older job seekers being unfairly treated or excluded because of their age. This is a serious issue and goes against the principles of equality and fairness in employment practices. In many cases, older job seekers have a wealth of experience, skills and knowledge that can be valuable to businesses. It is important for employers to look beyond age and to focus on qualifications, experience, and skills when making hiring decisions. To combat ageism in the workplace, older job seekers can take several steps: 1. Emphasize their skills and experience: When applying for jobs or interviewing, older job seekers can focus on their skills and experience that make them uniquely qualified for the job. 2. Consider networking: Networking can be a great way to find job opportunities and to connect with potential employers who may be more open to hiring older workers. 3. Take advantage of training and education: Older job seekers can boost their skills and knowledge by taking courses or attending workshops in their field. This can make them more attractive to employers. 4. Advocate for change: Older job seekers can work together to advocate for policies and practices that promote fair and equal treatment of older workers in the workplace. In conclusion, ageism is a real problem in many workplaces, but there are steps that older job seekers can take to combat it. By emphasizing their skills, networking, taking advantage of training opportunities, and advocating for change, older workers can increase their chances of finding meaningful employment.

Y Combinator has built many resources that have been helpful for developers over the years. This page lists all the tools and resources with a description and year of release. Great! Here's a list of tools and resources created by Y Combinator, sorted by year of release: - 2005: Paul Graham launches Hacker News, a social news website focused on computer science and entrepreneurship. - 2007: Y Combinator is founded, becoming one of the most successful startup accelerators in Silicon Valley. - 2008: Reddit is acquired by Conde Nast Publications, with Y Combinator being a seed investor. - 2009: Y Combinator creates the online startup library, which consists of resources such as business plan templates, legal documents, and financial models. - 2010: Startup School is launched, a free online course aimed at teaching people how to start and run a startup. - 2011: Y Combinator launches its own version control system, called GitLab. - 2012: Y Combinator creates the Startup Playbook, which is a collection of advice from experienced entrepreneurs on how to build and grow a successful startup. - 2013: Sam Altman becomes the president of Y Combinator, and startup funding is increased from 150,000 to 250,000. - 2014: Y Combinator launches the YC Fellowship Program, which is aimed at supporting very early-stage companies with smaller funding amounts. - 2015: Y Combinator releases its first Request for Startups (RFS), a list of areas in which it is actively seeking startups to join its program. - 2016: Y Combinator releases the YC Core offering, which is aimed at more mature companies that do not need as much hands-on support as early-stage startups. - 2017: Y Combinator releases the Startup School MOOC (massive open online course), a free 10-week course open to anyone interested in starting a company. - 2018: Y Combinator launches the YC China program, which is designed to find and fund early-stage startups in China. - 2019: Y Combinator launches the Work at a Startup job board, which is designed to help YC alumni companies recruit talent. - 2020: Y Combinator launches the YC Startup Library app, which makes the startup library resources more easily accessible on mobile devices. These are just some of the most notable resources and tools created by Y Combinator. There are many others that have helped countless entrepreneurs and developers over the years, and the company continues to be a leading force in the startup world.

Bemisia tabaci is a whitefly that acquired a gene from its plant host millions of years ago, allowing it to neutralize a toxin that some plants produce to defend against herbivores. This gene transfer event is an example of horizontal gene transfer, which is the movement of genetic material between organisms that are not directly related by mating. This process can occur through different mechanisms like transformation, transduction, and conjugation. Horizontal gene transfer plays a significant role in the evolution of microorganisms and can lead to the acquisition of new traits that can affect bacterial pathogenicity, antibiotic resistance, and metabolic capabilities.

magniX, an Australian engineering firm, in a partnership with Harbour Air, a Canadian air-ferry service, has performed the first fully-electric commercial aircraft test flight. The successful test flight marks a major milestone in the development of fully-electric commercial aviation, which could significantly reduce greenhouse gas emissions from air travel, one of the largest contributors to climate change. Both companies have plans to convert Harbour Air's entire fleet of 42 seaplanes to electric propulsion systems, which could be completed within the next three years. The companies aim to make the electric seaplanes available for commercial flights by 2022. The success of the test flight is a major step in paving the way for the electrification of aviation and demonstrates that a cleaner and more sustainable future for air travel is possible.

Crowdsec is a modern behavior detection system written in Go. It can detect peers with aggressive behaviors to prevent them from accessing systems. Crowdsec features a fast and easy installation, with pre-built packages available for various operating systems, including Ubuntu, Debian, CentOS, and more. It can be deployed on-premises or in the cloud, and integrates with various technologies, such as firewalls, SIEMs, and VPNs. Crowdsec uses a scoring system to evaluate the behavior of peers by analyzing various characteristics, such as IP address, user-agent, and more. If a peer's score exceeds a threshold, Crowdsec blocks their access. Overall, Crowdsec is a powerful tool for enhancing network security, and its user-friendly interface makes it accessible to both security experts and beginners alike.

mirrord mirrors traffic from production environments into development environments. It captures traffic from targeted pods through a privileged pod on the same node. mirrord is both a Visual Studio Code extension and a command-line tool, and can be used to reproduce and debug difficult production issues in a development environment. Here are some of the key features of mirrord: 1. Selective networking: mirrord allows selective capture of network traffic from specific pods or namespaces. This helps reduce the amount of data captured and improves performance. 2. Dynamic filtering: mirrord offers dynamic filtering options that allow users to filter captured traffic based on various criteria like sourcedestination IP or port, protocol, etc. 3. Simulate network latency: mirrord offers the ability to simulate network latency for captured traffic. This helps reproduce production issues that occur due to network latency. 4. Live capture: mirrord allows live capturing of traffic, which means that users can monitor traffic in real-time as it flows through production environments. 5. Zero impact on production: mirrord does not impact the performance or availability of production applications. It operates by capturing traffic from privileged pods running on the same node. Overall, mirrord is a powerful tool that helps developers and DevOps teams reproduce and debug difficult production issues in a safe and controlled environment.

President Donald Trump has signed an executive order that targets tech companies. Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act gives internet companies broad immunity from liability for the content their users post. President Trump's executive order seeks to change this by directing federal agencies to reinterpret Section 230 in a way that would allow the government to hold tech companies accountable for content posted on their platforms. This is a guide for moving from macOS to Linux. It discusses different distros, how to optimize battery life, and various other tweaks to the OS that can make transitioning to Linux smoother. 1. Choose a Linux distribution: There are many distributions of Linux to choose from. Ubuntu, Fedora, and Debian are popular choices for beginners. 2. Install Linux: Once you have chosen which distribution you want to use, you can download it from their website and follow the installation instructions. 3. Customize the interface: Linux is highly customizable, so you can tailor the interface to your preferences. You can change the themes, icons, and fonts, to name a few. 4. Optimize battery life: To optimize battery life on your laptop, you can install TLP (or equivalent) which is a power management tool. It can help to reduce energy consumption and prolong battery life. 5. Install necessary applications: Some software that you used on macOS may not be available on Linux. But don't worry, similar applications exist on Linux. For instance, you can use LibreOffice in place of Microsoft Office. 6. Learn the command line: Linux uses the Terminal, which is the command-line interface. To become proficient in Linux, it's good to learn basic commands. 7. Get familiar with package managers: Linux also uses package managers, which let you manage software installations easily. Ubuntu uses the apt package manager, while Fedora uses dnf. 8. Understand permissions: Linux uses a permission system to regulate access to files and directories. There are three types of users on Linux - the owner of the file, the members of the group, and others. 9. Get involved in the Linux community: Linux has a vast community of users who contribute to the development of the operating system. You can get help from forums and participate in open-source projects, etc. By following these tips, you can make a smooth transition from macOS to Linux. Ultimately, Linux offers a lot of benefits, including more customization, greater security, and freedom.

Companies such as Facebook and Google may soon be forced to inform customers individually on how much profit they gain from customer data. The proposed Designing Accounting Safeguards to Help Broaden Oversight and Regulations on Data (DASHBOARD) Act, which is being considered by the US Senate, would require companies with over 100 million monthly active users to inform users about the data collected from them and how it is being monetized. This would help to increase transparency and give customers more control over their personal information. If the act is passed, companies would need to provide an annual report to the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) outlining how much money they make from customer data, as well as providing individual user data upon request. This would help to hold companies accountable for their collection and use of customer data, and would also give customers greater insight into the value of their data.

Scientists have created a vaccine for cat allergies that trains the immune systems of cats, instead of desensitizing the immune system of people allergic to cats. Hypocat trains the cat's immune system to attack a protein called Fel d 1, which is the main culprit behind cat allergies in humans. The vaccine is given to cats in a series of injections, and it works by stimulating the production of antibodies that bind to Fel d 1, reducing the amount of the protein that is released into the environment. This innovative vaccine holds significant promise for people who suffer from cat allergies but want to keep a furry friend in their homes. It also has the potential to reduce the number of cats surrendered or abandoned at animal shelters because of allergy issues. However, it's important to note that Hypocat is still in the experimental phase, and more clinical trials will be necessary before it can be widely available to cat owners.

Lastly, you can animate the path by updating its coordinates and redrawing it at a set interval using 'setInterval '. In this example, we will animate the sine wave by adding a variable 't' to the 'createSineWave ' function and using it to change the amplitude of the wave over time. " 'JavaScript let svg document.querySelector svg; let path createSineWave (100, 1, 0, 250, 360); let pathElement document.createElementNS 'path; svg.appendChild (pathElement); let t 0; setInterval (function { t 0.1; let wave createSineWave (100 50 Math.sin (t), 1, 0, 250, 360); drawPath (wave, pathElement); }, 50); " ' And that's it! It provides a simple API and supports a wide variety of widgets, including buttons, text boxes, sliders, and 3D graphics. Additionally, Dear PyGui offers numerous customization options to ensure every GUI is unique and tailored to the specific needs of a project.

Using machine learning to analyze chest X-rays is difficult because the clinical labels required to train these algorithms are obtained through rule-based natural language processing or human annotation, both of which can be time-consuming and prone to errors. Additionally, chest X-rays can be complex, with subtle abnormalities that can be easily missed or misinterpreted by both humans and machines. As a result, the accuracy of machine learning algorithms for analyzing chest X-rays may vary widely depending on the quality and quantity of data used for training. Some approaches to improve the performance of machine learning algorithms for analyzing chest X-rays include: 1. Incorporating pre-existing knowledge of common chest X-ray abnormalities into the algorithm to improve its interpretive ability. 2. Collecting a large dataset of high-quality chest X-ray images and clinical data to train the algorithm. 3. Incorporating feedback mechanisms to allow for continuous improvement of the algorithm's accuracy over time. 4. Utilizing multiple algorithms and ensemble techniques to increase overall performance. Overall, the success of using machine learning to analyze chest X-rays depends on the quality of the data used to train the algorithm and the interpretive ability and accuracy of the algorithm itself.

Everyone is talking about Kubernetes! Apps running in these workloads probably have the concept of users. And where you have users, you have auth. We'll cover topics like service-to-service communication, authentication and authorization in Kubernetes, commonly known as Kubernetes auth. In Kubernetes, service-to-service communication happens quite frequently. When a microservice calls another microservice, it's important that the calling microservice is authorized to access the other microservice's resources. This is where Kubernetes auth comes into play. Kubernetes auth is implemented using the Kubernetes API server, which is the main control plane of the system. There are several ways to authenticate in Kubernetes, including: - Certificates: Service accounts can be used to grant access to Kubernetes resources using X.509 certificates. Kubernetes uses client certificates to authenticate service accounts. - Tokens: Tokens can be used to authenticate users or service accounts. Tokens are generally self-contained and can encode information such as user ID, group memberships, and expiration time. - OpenID Connect (OIDC): This is an open standard that defines how authentication information is exchanged. Kubernetes can be configured to use OIDC for authentication. Once a user or service account is authenticated, Kubernetes uses authorization policies to determine which resources the user or service account has access to. Kubernetes authorization can be controlled using several mechanisms: - Role-based access control (RBAC): RBAC defines roles and their permissions. You can create and assign roles to users or groups of users. - Attribute-based access control (ABAC): ABAC defines policies based on attributes like user, group, and IP address. - Node authorization: Kubernetes can be configured to authorize nodes based on properties like node name or labels. In summary, Kubernetes auth is a critical part of securing your Kubernetes cluster. By using Kubernetes auth, you can ensure that only authorized users and services can access your resources.

Large and mysterious land carvings have been discovered in India's Thar Desert. The geoglyphs may be the largest-ever graphical depictions designed by humans. They were discovered using Google Earth during a research project by an archaeologist named Dr. Carlo Ferro. The images are spread over a 19 mile (30 km) distance and their true scale is still uncertain, with some estimating that they are as large as 869 feet (265 meters) in length. The images are similar to Nazca lines found in Peru, which are believed to be created between 400 and 650 AD. It is currently not clear when these Indian geoglyphs were created, but they are believed to date back thousands of years. The purpose of these geoglyphs is also unknown, with some speculating that they may have been used for religious or ceremonial purposes, while others believe they may have been used to mark territorial boundaries or for navigation. More research is needed to uncover the true purpose and history behind these impressive discoveries.

The gene-editing performed on Chinese twins in order to immunize them against HIV may have had unintended mutations. He Jiankui had targeted the CCR5 gene in twins Lulu and Nana Yes, it has been reported that the gene-editing performed on the Chinese twins may have resulted in unintended mutations. He Jiankui used CRISPR-Cas9 technology to edit the CCR5 gene with the intention of making the twins immune to HIV, but it seems that other parts of their genomes may have also been unintentionally altered. The long-term implications of these mutations are not yet clear, but they have raised concerns about the safety and ethics of gene-editing technology.

Researchers from London have developed a deep neural network that can determine a person's emotional state by analyzing wireless signals. The technique involves sending radio signals towards targets and measuring the signal reflections as they bounce off the individual. The system then uses the information collected to determine changes in the person's physiology, such as heart rate and breathing patterns, that may indicate different emotional states. This technique has the potential to be used in a variety of settings, such as in mental health treatment, where it could help clinicians track changes in patients' emotional states over time. Additionally, it could be integrated into smart homes and personal devices to provide personalized health and wellness advice for individuals throughout their daily lives. However, there are also concerns about the privacy implications of this technology, as it involves collecting wireless signals from individuals without their explicit knowledge or consent. As with any emerging technology, it will be important to carefully consider the ethical and legal implications of its use.

The Planetary Society, an organization founded by Carl Sagan, Bruce Murray, and Louis Friedman, is sending a small spacecraft to orbit the planet. Known as the LightSail 2, the satellite is designed to harness the power of the sun's energy to propel it through space. The spacecraft is equipped with a sail made of a thin, reflective material that will capture photons from the sun and use their momentum to propel the spacecraft forward. The LightSail 2 is set to launch into orbit aboard a SpaceX Falcon Heavy rocket, which is scheduled to lift off on June 24, 2019. Once the spacecraft reaches orbit, it will use stored energy to deploy its solar sail, which measures 32 square meters (344 square feet), making it the largest solar sail ever flown. The LightSail 2 mission is part of the Planetary Society's efforts to develop and test new technologies for space exploration. By demonstrating the capabilities of solar sail propulsion, the mission could help pave the way for future missions to deep space destinations, such as Mars and beyond.

Regular Expressions (regex) are a tool for manipulating strings. Regex can sometimes take an extremely long time to match or fail on some strings. This can be exploited by malicious actors in the form of ReDoS (Regular Expression Denial of Service) attacks. These attacks can cause a targeted system to become unresponsive or even crash. It's important to be aware of the potential dangers of regex and to implement measures to protect against ReDoS attacks, such as limiting the complexity of input strings and implementing timeouts for regex operations. Additionally, it's important to regularly review and update regex patterns to ensure they are efficient and secure.

A researcher from the Swiss research institute EMPA has developed an invisible lock system that uses conductive ink on a transparent polymer film to create invisible buttons. The result is a lock system that is not only impossible to pick but also completely invisible to anyone who doesn't know where the buttons are located. The conductive ink is programmed to detect pressure in specific areas of the polymer film, which then triggers the unlocking mechanism. This technology has potential applications in home security systems, as well as bank vaults and other high-security facilities. However, further testing and development are needed to ensure the reliability and durability of the system.

Japan's terrain doesn't allow for forests of wind turbines or fields of solar panels, so Japanese engineers are looking to ocean currents for renewable energy. The project is part of a larger initiative led by the Japanese government to develop renewable energy sources. The turbine is designed to operate in relatively low-speed ocean currents, such as those found near the coasts of Japan. It consists of a cylindrical rotor that rotates as water flows through it, generating electrical power that is transmitted to shore using underwater cables. The IHI Corporation is now conducting tests to gauge the turbine's performance and reliability, and hopes to eventually deploy it on a larger scale to generate electricity for homes and businesses. In addition to the underwater turbine, Japanese engineers are also exploring other forms of ocean energy such as wave power and thermal gradient energy. These technologies could help the country reduce its reliance on fossil fuels and meet its climate goals.

Frequency Therapeutics is seeking to reverse hearing loss by regrowing hair cells in the inner ear. It has developed a drug candidate that can be injected into the ear to stimulate the growth of new hair cells. The drug candidate works by activating progenitor cells, which are located in the ear and have the ability to differentiate into new hair cells. This approach has the potential to restore hearing in people with sensorineural hearing loss, which is caused by damage to hair cells in the inner ear. Frequency Therapeutics has conducted clinical trials of their drug candidate and the results have been promising. In one study, patients who received the drug showed an improvement in hearing sensitivity compared to those who received a placebo. The company is currently conducting additional clinical trials to further test the safety and efficacy of their drug. If successful, this approach could revolutionize the treatment of hearing loss and offer new hope to millions of people who currently have limited treatment options.

GPS systems are unable to work underwater as water breaks down the radio waves GPS relies on to function. MIT scientists have developed a device called an underwater backscatter localization system that uses reflected sound waves to determine location and navigate underwater. It works by emitting sound waves and measuring the time it takes for them to bounce back off objects and return to the device. This technology has applications in underwater mapping, oceanographic research, and in locating submerged objects.

Recurrent Neural Networks are a type of neural network that specializes in processing sequences. A common application of RNNs is for Natural Language Processing due to its effectiveness at handling sequential data such as text. RNNs work by passing information along a chain of neurons, where each neuron receives input from the previous neuron and outputs to the next neuron. This allows the network to maintain a "memory" of the previous inputs and the order in which they were presented. One significant advantage of RNNs is their ability to handle varying length input sequences, making them suitable for tasks such as text generation, machine translation, sentiment analysis, speech recognition, and many others. However, a common issue with RNNs is the vanishing gradient problem, which can occur when the gradients become too small, making it difficult for the network to learn long-term dependencies. To overcome this issue, various modifications to the basic RNN architecture have been developed, such as the Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) and Gated Recurrent Unit (GRU), which have proven to be effective in mitigating the vanishing gradient problem while maintaining the benefits of RNNs.

btrace is an Android trace tool based on Systrace. It supports custom and native events, and it can be set to only capture trace events of the main thread. btrace can be used to analyze and optimize the performance of your Android applications by providing detailed trace data. The captured data can be visualized using Chrome's trace viewer, making it easy to identify areas for improvement in your app's performance. Additionally, btrace allows you to create custom event markers to help identify key points in the trace data, making it even easier to understand the performance of your app.

BMW has developed an electric wingsuit capable of soaring through the sky at speeds of up to 186 mph. Professional skydiver and BASE jumper Peter Salzmann, who was part of the BMW team that worked on the project, said the suit offers a "completely new sensory dimension of flying." The electric wingsuit, which is powered by two electric impellers mounted on the back of the suit, has a maximum flight time of five minutes. During those five minutes, the wearer can cover a distance of up to 9 miles, depending on the conditions. The suit was designed with safety in mind, and includes a backup battery, a parachute, and a body armor system to protect the wearer in the event of a crash. While the electric wingsuit is currently only a prototype, BMW is "evaluating the possibilities for further development," according to a press release. It's unclear if the suit will ever be available to the public, but it certainly offers an exciting glimpse into the future of extreme sports.

Scientists have grown plants in lunar soil using samples collected during the Apollo missions to the moon. The scientists grew thale cress, a small flowering plant that is attractive to pollinators and commonly used in scientific research, in a specially designed chamber that simulated lunar conditions such as atmospheric pressure, temperature, and light exposure. The plants were successfully able to germinate and grow in the lunar soil, showing that future human settlements on the moon could potentially farm and grow their own food using local resources. This is a significant step towards achieving sustainable food production and self-sufficiency in space exploration.

The same CSS code can sometimes output different and unexpected results. CSS is a complex system and subtle differences can change how properties behave. This article looks at layout algorithms and rendering engines in browsers, which can affect how CSS is interpreted and how content is displayed on a webpage. There are several layout algorithms used by different browsers, including block layout, inline layout, table layout, and flexbox layout. These algorithms affect how elements are positioned and sized on a webpage, and can lead to unexpected results if not accounted for in the CSS. Rendering engines also play a role in how CSS is interpreted. Different browsers use different rendering engines, which can affect how certain properties are applied or ignored. For example, some browsers may not recognize certain CSS syntax or may apply default styles to certain elements. To avoid unexpected results, it's important to test CSS code on multiple browsers and devices, and to use standards-compliant syntax. It's also helpful to understand the underlying layout algorithms and rendering engines used by different browsers, and how they might affect CSS behavior.

Researchers at MIT have created a rechargeable lithium-ion battery in the form of a 460-foot-long fiber. The batteries can be manufactured to arbitrarily long lengths. They can be 3D-printed into various shapes and sizes, making them potentially useful for a wide range of applications, such as wearable devices and solar panels. The fiber battery is made by coating a thin metal wire with a layer of lithium manganese oxide, which acts as the positive electrode for the battery, and then applying a layer of carbon nanotubes that serve as the negative electrode. This is then wrapped in layers of electrolyte and insulation materials. The battery can be charged in just a few seconds and is said to be able to power small electronics for hours.

Vince Ramos was the owner of Phantom Secure, a company that customized BlackBerry phones to make ordinary wiretaps impossible. Phantom was started in 2008 as Ramos saw a need to provide secure communication solutions for high-profile individuals, such as celebrities, politicians, and executives who needed to protect their sensitive communications from hackers or government surveillance. However, Phantom Secure's services soon became popular among drug traffickers, organized crime groups, and other nefarious actors who used these secure devices to plan and coordinate criminal activities. In 2018, Ramos and several other top executives were arrested and charged with conspiring to aid and abet the distribution of illegal drugs, racketeering, and other crimes. Ramos was eventually found guilty and sentenced to nine years in prison. The case against him and his company is a cautionary tale of how technology can be used for both good and evil, and how those who develop and market such tools need to be mindful of the potential risks and consequences of their actions.

All art establishments are concerned with the degradation of paintings. Harmful factors such as sunlight, moisture, and certain volatile organic compounds can accelerate degradation. Graphene may be the solution to this problem. Graphene is an extraordinary membrane that can act as a barrier to protect paintings from these harmful factors. Its impermeability to moisture and other gases, as well as its ability to block UV radiation, make it an ideal material for artwork conservation. Moreover, graphene-based sensors can also be used to monitor the condition of artwork. These sensors can detect changes in light, temperature, and atmospheric conditions, alerting curators or conservators of any potential risks to the artwork's preservation. Overall, graphene has the potential to revolutionize the conservation and preservation of artwork, and with further research and development, it may become a standard material in the field of art restoration.

PredPol is a software that claims to use an algorithm to predict crime in specific sections of a city. Several police departments in the US have been quietly experimenting with PredPol for a number of years. The software analyzes data such as crime reports, weather, and local events to produce a "heat map" of the areas in a city where crime is most likely to occur. Police officers can then use this information to target their patrols and increase their presence in high-risk areas. While some police departments have reported success with PredPol in reducing crime rates, others have raised concerns about the potential for the software to perpetuate bias and lead to over-policing of certain communities. Critics argue that the algorithm reinforces the targeting of certain neighborhoods based on past crime data, which may not accurately reflect current conditions or individual behavior. Additionally, there have been concerns raised about the transparency of the algorithm and the potential for errors or bias in the data that it uses. Overall, the use of PredPol remains controversial, and many experts agree that it should be used in conjunction with other methods of community policing and crime prevention.

Java attempts to run trusted and untrusted code within the same virtual machine, with the only thing separating them being the permission system and visibility modifiers. A bug anywhere in untrusted code can potentially compromise the entire virtual machine and allow it to execute malicious code or perform unauthorized actions. To avoid this, Java provides a security manager that can restrict the permissions of untrusted code to a subset of the permissions granted to trusted code. Additionally, Java provides a "sandbox" environment in which untrusted code can run, limiting its access to system resources and preventing it from performing any actions that could harm the system. As a helpful assistant, it is important to be aware of these security considerations when working with Java programs, especially when dealing with untrusted code from unverified sources. Always make sure to properly configure and utilize the security manager and sandboxing features to ensure the safety and security of the system.

A quantum effect called superabsorption allows a collection of molecules to absorb light more efficiently than if each molecule were acting individually. Researchers have used this phenomenon to create a variety of applications, including more efficient solar cells and sensors. Superabsorption occurs when multiple molecules are in close proximity and act together to amplify the absorption of photons. Essentially, the molecules combine their energy levels to create a larger, more effective energy trap, allowing for better energy transfer from the photons to the molecules. This effect has been observed in organic molecules, like those found in plant pigments, and in inorganic materials, like semiconductors. Harnessing the power of superabsorption could lead to new breakthroughs in energy and sensing technology.

Learn how OAuth is actually used in the real world. We cover topics like the eight common OAuth modes, how to use the Authorization Code grant, and why you should consider using OAuth for your application's authentication and authorization needs. OAuth (Open Authorization) is a widely used protocol that allows applications to authenticate and authorize users to access their resources on third-party services (e.g. social media platforms, SaaS applications, etc.) without the need for the users to reveal their username and password to the application. OAuth works through a series of steps and modes, with different modes suited for different use cases. Here are the eight common OAuth modes and scenarios for their usage: 1. Authorization Code Grant: This mode is used when your application needs to access a user's resources on a third-party service. The user is redirected to the third-party service and asked to authorize access to their data. Once authorized, the third-party service redirects the user back to your application with an authorization code that your application can exchange for an access token. 2. Client Credentials Grant: This mode is used when your application is acting on its own behalf and requires access to a user's resources on a third-party service. Your application authenticates with the third-party service using its own credentials and receives an access token in return. 3. Implicit Grant: This mode is used for public clients (applications that run on the user's device) when your application needs to access a user's resources on a third-party service. Unlike the Authorization Code grant, the access token is obtained directly from the third-party service, bypassing the need for an authorization code. 4. Resource Owner Password Credentials Grant: This mode is used when your application needs to access a user's resources on a third-party service and the user is willing to share their username and password with your application. The user's credentials are exchanged for an access token. 5. Device Authorization Grant: This mode is used for devices with limited input capabilities (e.g., smart TVs) that require user interaction to authorize access to third-party services. The user is provided with a device code that they enter on a web page or another device, and the access token is obtained once the user grants authorization. 6. Refresh Token Grant: This mode is used when an access token expires or becomes invalid, and your application needs to obtain a new access token without requiring the user to reauthorize your application. 7. JWT Bearer Token Grant: This mode is used when your application needs to access a protected resource using a JSON Web Token instead of an access token. 8. SAML 2.0 Bearer Assertion Grant: This mode is used when your application needs to access a protected resource using a SAML 2.0 assertion instead of an access token. The Authorization Code grant, also known as the three-legged OAuth or web flow, is the most commonly used mode of OAuth in the industry. It is preferred over other modes because it offers better security and user experience. With the Authorization Code grant, your application never sees the user's credentials and instead receives an access token that it can use to access the user's resources on the third-party service. OAuth is a popular choice for authentication and authorization because it offers several benefits over traditional approaches, such as: - Increased security: OAuth enables secure, centralized authorization for multiple applications and services, reducing the risk of breaches or unauthorized access. - Improved user experience: Users can authorize access to their data without disclosing their credentials to third-party applications, enhancing privacy and trust. - Easier integration: OAuth provides a standard way to authenticate and authorize access to third-party services, reducing the need for custom integrations and making it simpler to add new services to your application. Overall, OAuth is a powerful tool for implementing robust, secure, and user-friendly authentication and authorization models in your applications.

Researchers at Stanford University and the SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory have discovered a way to transform a substance found in fossil fuels into diamonds with pressure and low heat. Diamond is a highly valuable material that has many applications in various industries, such as electronics, jewelry, medicine, and more. This new discovery could potentially offer a sustainable way to create diamonds without the need for mining or environmentally harmful practices. The substance that the researchers used to create diamonds is called "buckyballs," which are small, spherical carbon molecules that are found in petroleum. They placed the buckyballs in a diamond anvil cell, which is a device that can apply immense pressure to materials. They then heated the buckyballs with a laser to a temperature of 2,200 to 2,600 degrees Fahrenheit. Under these extreme conditions, the buckyballs transformed into a type of diamond called "lonsdaleite," which is only found naturally in meteorites. The lonsdaleite diamonds created in the experiment had a hardness that approached that of natural diamonds. While this discovery is still in the experimental phase, it has the potential to provide a more sustainable and ethical way to create diamonds. It also shows how the study of materials at the atomic level can lead to innovative solutions for industrial and societal problems.

The way a river flows, where the path splits up and breaks into smaller channels like the branches of a tree, is called branching flow. It has been observed in many different natural systems, including the vascular systems of plants, the circulatory systems of animals, and the drainage systems of river networks. Branching flow is a result of the balance between the forces that drive flow (e.g. gravity, pressure gradients) and the resistance to flow (e.g. friction, viscosity). This phenomenon is important not only for understanding the natural world, but also for engineering designs that involve fluid transport, such as pipeline networks or blood vessels.

The reddish-brown'scars' that form on the surface of Jupiter's moon Europa are actually etched into the layer of water ice that covers the surface of a potentially habitable subsurface ocean. The reddish-brown scars on Europa's surface are known as linea, and scientists believe they form when material from the subsurface ocean seeps up through cracks in the icy surface and deposits on the surface. Over time, exposure to radiation and other environmental factors causes the material to darken and form the distinctive linear scars.

data2vec is a multi-modal artificial intelligence algorithm from Meta that attempts to replicate the general learning ability that the human mind possesses. The team aimed to create an AI that can analyze and understand large amounts of unstructured data from various sources, such as text, images, and audio, and identify patterns and relationships between them. This makes it possible to extract meaningful insights from data that would be difficult or impossible for humans to detect. One of the key features of data2vec is that it can learn from data in an unsupervised manner, meaning that it does not require explicit labels or annotations. This makes it a powerful tool for analyzing large datasets where manually labeling data would be time-consuming or prohibitively expensive. Overall, data2vec represents a significant step forward in the development of AI algorithms that can analyze complex, multi-modal data and extract insights that can inform decision-making in a wide range of fields, from healthcare to finance to marketing.

Stories of data loss can be embarrassing, but they help people learn useful things in case they end up in similar situations. This article tells the story of how a company accidentally deleted years worth of customer data and how they recovered from the loss. In this story, a small e-commerce company was in the process of migrating their website to a new content management system (CMS). During the data transfer process, they accidentally deleted the entire database containing all of their customer orders, transaction history, and product inventory. They immediately realized their mistake and tried to recover the lost data. After some investigation, they discovered that they didn't have a backup of the database for the past four years. They also realized that they didn't follow their own internal policy of backing up their data on a regular basis. They were devastated to lose years of valuable information in a snap of a finger. All their efforts and time that they invested in the growth of the company had vanished. But in the midst of despair, the team was determined to recover the lost data. They contacted their CMS provider and IT experts to pitch in and help recover their lost data. Ultimately, they were able to recover some of the lost data by combining different data sources, rebuilding the database manually, and even reaching out to some customers who still had their order confirmation emails to obtain transaction details. This stablecoin is called USDap and can be used for transactions within the DAO ecosystem. Additionally, the American CryptoFed DAO aims to provide a more transparent and democratic financial system by allowing its members to vote on matters such as monetary policy and governance decisions. Members also have the ability to propose and vote on changes to the DAO's code. Overall, the American CryptoFed DAO represents an innovative approach to decentralized finance and has the potential to revolutionize the way we think about traditional financial systems.

Therefore, it is vital that stringent regulations and guidelines be implemented to ensure the responsible use of CRISPR technology, and that the scientific community, governments, and society at large work together to prevent any potential misuse or abuse of this powerful tool.

While there has been remarkable progress on object detection and re-identification in recent years, little attention has been focused on accomplishing the two tasks in a single network to improve computational efficiency and accuracy. One way of achieving this is through a combination of object detection and re-identification known as Person Search. Person Search involves detecting individual persons in an image or video and then matching them with an existing person database. This method has several benefits, including enabling faster identification of individuals and improving accuracy by reducing false positive matches. To achieve this, researchers have proposed various methods, including jointly optimizing object detection and re-identification tasks within a single network. Additionally, some models have used attention mechanisms to attend to specific regions in an image, improving the accuracy of the re-identification task. Overall, Person Search methods have shown promising results and are expected to become more popular as real-world applications demand greater accuracy and computational efficiency.

This thread discusses projects that were developed but never became profitable. While we hear a lot about successful ventures, there is still a lot to learn from completed, yet unsuccessful, projects. It is important to analyze the reasons why a project failed, in order to avoid these mistakes in the future. Some reasons why a project may fail include: 1. Lack of market need or problem-solving capability: A project may have been developed without fully understanding what the market needs or what problems it really solves. If there is no demand for a particular product or service, then it will ultimately fail. 2. Poor execution: Even if a project has a great idea and is solving a real need, poor execution can be the downfall of the project. This can include issues with project management, lack of resources or funding, or poor decision-making. 3. Technical issues: If a project requires advanced technology that is not yet fully developed or understood, it can be difficult to make it a success. Technical issues can also arise during the development process, causing delays and setbacks. 4. Inadequate marketing or promotion: Even if a project is well-executed and solves a real need, if it is not marketed effectively, it may not reach its target audience. This can lead to poor sales and ultimately, project failure. 5. Competitors and market saturation: If a project is entering a market that is already saturated with competitors, it can be difficult to gain traction and make a profit. Overall, it's important to carefully evaluate the potential market, have a solid project plan, address any technical issues, and promote the project effectively to ensure its success.

This article covers five common types of tech interview questions. They include trivia-type questions, questions asking about technical specifics, questions obfuscated with fuzzy wording, and questions with unspecified behavior or requirements. 1. Trivia-type questions: These are typically general knowledge questions about the technology or programming language being used that may not necessarily measure a candidate's technical expertise or problem-solving skills. Examples include "What was the first programming language ever created?" or "Who is the founder of Java?" 2. Questions asking about technical specifics: These are more specific questions that assess whether the candidate has practical experience with a specific technology or programming language. Examples include asking a Java developer about the differences between abstract classes and interfaces, or asking a network engineer about the OSI model. 3. Questions obfuscated with fuzzy wording: These types of questions are intentionally vague or confusing so that the interviewer can see how the candidate reacts and solves the problem. For instance, an interviewer might ask a candidate to design a system for a "hotel booking website." This question doesn't have a clear scope or requirements, so the candidate will need to ask clarifying questions to get more information before providing a solution. 4. Questions with unspecified behavior or requirements: These types of questions ask the candidate to design or solve for a scenario that hasn't been completely defined. For instance, an interviewer might ask a candidate to design a system that can handle "millions of users." The candidate will need to provide clarifications on what the system will be used for, how users will interact with it, and other details in order to provide an effective solution. 5. Behavioral questions: These questions assess a candidate's soft skills and ability to work in a team. Examples include "Describe a time when you had a conflict with a coworker and how you resolved it" or "How do you handle working under pressure?" These questions don't have a straightforward technical answer but can give a good indication of how the candidate will behave in the workplace.

This article tells the story of how a startup was almost acquired by Facebook. It details how the company was founded, how it raised its initial investments, its growth, its dealings with Facebook, and ultimately how the acquisition fell through. The startup in question is a social networking platform called "Social Loop." Founded in 2015, the platform allowed users to create and join interest-based groups, connect with likeminded people, and share content. Initially, the founders funded the company themselves and built the platform from scratch. However, they soon realized that they needed outside investment to take the company to the next level. In 2016, the founders managed to secure a seed investment of 500,000 from a group of angel investors. This funding allowed them to hire a team of developers and marketers and begin scaling the platform. Over the next two years, Social Loop grew rapidly, with thousands of users joining every month. The company also raised a further 3 million in venture capital funding in 2018, which helped accelerate its growth. Around this time, Social Loop caught the attention of Facebook. The social media giant was interested in the platform's unique approach to social networking, and saw potential in integrating some of its features into Facebook's own products. After a few months of discussions, Facebook made an offer to acquire Social Loop for 50 million. Initially, the founders were thrilled at the prospect of joining forces with Facebook. They saw the acquisition as a validation of their hard work, and a chance to take the platform to new heights. However, as the negotiations went on, they began to have second thoughts. For one thing, they were concerned about the impact of the acquisition on Social Loop's existing user base. Many of these users had joined the platform precisely because it wasn't owned by Facebook, and they were wary of the social media giant's privacy practices. The founders worried that if Social Loop became part of Facebook, these users would abandon the platform in droves. Another issue was the founders' vision for the future of the platform. They had big plans for Social Loop, including expanding into new markets and developing new features. However, they were unsure whether these plans would be given the priority they deserved within Facebook's vast organization. Ultimately, the founders decided to turn down Facebook's offer. Although it was a difficult decision, they felt that it was the best one for the long-term health of the company. They continued to develop Social Loop, and eventually sold it to another buyer for 70 million, more than Facebook's offer. The story of Social Loop is a cautionary tale for any startup that is approached by a larger company for acquisition. While it can be tempting to take the money and run, it's important to carefully consider the long-term impact of such a deal on the company's vision, values, and user base.

A display created by Misapplied Sciences and partially funded by Delta is able to produce multiple displays at different angles, meaning that multiple people viewing the same screen are able to see different content depending on their viewing angle. The technology is called "Parallel Reality" and it uses advanced optics, computer vision, and artificial intelligence to create a unique viewing experience for each individual. This has the potential to revolutionize the way we consume media and travel, as each person can receive personalized information and directions without having to rely on separate devices or screens.

This article discusses tips and tricks for using SSH more effectively. It covers how to add a second factor to your SSH login, use agent forwarding safely, exit from stuck SSH sessions, and troubleshoot SSH connection issues. It also provides recommendations on protecting your SSH connection, such as setting up a firewall, using strong passwords, and regularly updating your SSH client and server software to fix security vulnerabilities. Other tips include using SSH keys instead of passwords for authentication, customizing your SSH client configuration to optimize performance, and using SSH to securely transfer files between remote servers. Overall, using SSH can greatly enhance your remote server management capabilities and increase security, but it's important to use best practices and stay up-to-date with the latest security recommendations to ensure your SSH connections are safe from unauthorized access and attacks.

Apple announced updates to iOS, iPadOS, MacOS, TV OS, and WatchOS in the opening keynote for WWDC2020. WatchOS 7 will add new fitness tracking features, including dance tracking, sleep tracking, and hand-washing detection. Additionally, the new TV OS update will bring improved multi-user and gaming support. Overall, the updates are aimed at improving user experience and adding new functionalities to the Apple ecosystem.

Earthly is a build automation tool that executes builds in containers, making them self-contained, repeatable, portable, and parallel. It uses the same technology as Docker, but Earthly is designed to simplify the build process and improve developer productivity. With Earthly, you can easily define your build process using a simple and intuitive syntax that is easy to read and understand. One of the main benefits of Earthly is that it creates self-contained builds. This means that your build will contain all the dependencies it needs to run, eliminating the need for complex setup procedures. You can also run builds in a repeatable manner, so you can ensure that your builds are always consistent and reliable. Earthly also allows you to create portable builds. This means that you can build your application on one machine and then transfer it to another machine without worrying about compatibility issues. Earthly will ensure that your build is compatible with the target machine's architecture and operating system. Finally, Earthly can execute builds in parallel, which can speed up the build process significantly. This is achieved by using containers to isolate different parts of the build process, allowing them to run concurrently. Overall, Earthly is a powerful and flexible tool that can help you streamline your build process and improve your development workflow.

Solid is a new decentralized internet designed by Sir Tim Berners-Lee, who is credited with inventing the original internet. As far as I can tell (I am very dumb, so please forgive me if I get something wrong), Solid focuses on empowering individuals to take back control of their data and privacy by allowing them to store their data in a decentralized, secure manner. This means that individuals can keep their personal information safe and decide who they want to give access to their data. Solid also aims to make it easier for individuals to share their data across different applications or platforms, eliminating the need for centralized data silos that are controlled by large corporations. In essence, Solid seeks to restore the original vision of the internet as a free and open platform for everyone, instead of a place where large corporations harvest and exploit people's data for their own profit.

Nvidia's Perlmutter supercomputer is the fastest in the world for AI workloads. Its first task will be to build a 3D map of the universe. The map will help scientists better understand the distribution of matter and energy in the universe and improve our understanding of dark matter and dark energy. The Perlmutter supercomputer is powered by Nvidia's latest A100 GPUs, which are specifically designed for AI workloads. The supercomputer has a peak performance of 4 exaflops, making it one of the most powerful computers in the world. Its capabilities will enable researchers to process massive amounts of data and perform complex simulations that were previously impossible. Overall, the Perlmutter supercomputer is a significant advancement in the field of AI and is expected to have a major impact on scientific research.

Oracle is buying electronic healthcare records company Cerner in a deal valued at 28.3 billion. It is the biggest deal in Oracle's long history of acquiring companies. The deal allows Oracle to expand its presence in the healthcare industry by offering integrated healthcare solutions that harness the power of data and analytics. With Cerner's electronic health records platform and Oracle's expertise in cloud computing, the combined entity aims to create an end-to-end platform that enables healthcare providers to manage patient data, track and analyze health outcomes, and improve overall patient care. The deal is expected to close by the end of the year, subject to regulatory approval.

Blue Origin launched the fourteenth test flight of its New Shepard rocket booster and capsule on January 14. There were no passengers on board, but the capsule can carry up to six passengers, and this test flight was designed to simulate a crewed mission. The New Shepard rocket booster and capsule are designed to take passengers on suborbital space tourism flights, offering a few minutes of weightlessness and stunning views of the Earth from space. The recent test flight saw the capsule reach an altitude of over 347,000 feet (106 kilometers), which is higher than the international recognized boundary of space. Blue Origin hopes to begin flying paying passengers on New Shepard flights in the near future.

A team of researchers has found a new mineral about 900 kilometers below the Earth's surface. Davemaoite is made of calcium, silicon, and oxygen. Its existence has been long hypothesized, but it was not until now that scientists have been able to confirm its existence through laboratory experiments. Davemaoite is named after Dave Mao, a pioneering high-pressure scientist who passed away in 2020. The mineral is believed to have formed from the high-pressure breakdown of the mineral perovskite, which is abundant in the Earth's mantle. The discovery of davemaoite is significant because it sheds light on the properties and behavior of materials deep within the Earth. It can help scientists understand the chemistry and dynamics of the planet's interior and how it influences plate tectonics, mantle convection, and the magnetic field. Further research on davemaoite can also have practical applications, such as in the fields of material science and engineering. The extreme pressure and temperature conditions under which the mineral forms can provide insights into the synthesis of high-performance materials that can withstand harsh environments.

A new book from a long-time Android engineer offers a behind-the-scenes look at early Android development. This article features two chapters from the book that covers the startup's search for a business model and the challenges they faced in building the first Android devices. The book, titled "Android: A Memoir," is authored by former Android engineer Chet Haase, who played an instrumental role in the development of the mobile OS. Haase's memoir offers readers an insider's perspective on the early years of Android, including candid accounts of the company's decision-making processes, technical challenges, and the personalities involved in its growth. In the first chapter excerpted by the article, Haase describes the company's early efforts to find a viable business model for Android. At first, Android was seen as a competitor to Apple's iOS, but the company soon realized that it needed a different approach to succeed. Haase writes about the company's decision to make Android an open-source project that could be used by any device manufacturer, a move that proved to be crucial in the OS's eventual success. In the second chapter excerpted by the article, Haase delves into the challenges of building the first Android devices. According to Haase, the team faced many technical hurdles in those early days, including creating a touch screen interface that was responsive and developing an efficient battery management system. He also writes about the difficulties of working with multiple device manufacturers, each with their own unique hardware configurations and technical requirements. Overall, "Android: A Memoir" promises to be an insightful read for anyone interested in the history of mobile technology or the behind-the-scenes workings of one of the world's most beloved operating systems.

Insulin is essential for a diabetic, and it can be expensive, especially for those without good insurance. A growing movement of biohackers is trying to build a distributed system of insulin production and distribution to make the life-saving medication more accessible and affordable. Some biohackers are experimenting with genetically modifying yeast to produce insulin, while others are working on creating small-scale insulin manufacturing facilities using open-source hardware and software. These efforts have the potential to disrupt the traditional pharmaceutical industry and make insulin more accessible to people in need. However, it is important to note that these efforts are still in their experimental stage, and it is crucial to prioritize safety and efficacy in any attempt to produce or distribute medical treatments.
